Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of Testbed Platform for Advanced Multi-Stage Automation and Control for Smart and Micro Grid

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The development of flexible electric power and energy systems that are secure, resilient to attack, sustainable and affordable in an environmentally friendly manner has become a national priority. Industries, government, National Laboratories, and various agencies, such as the military (for its bases), are looking for a testbed to test the design of a flexible micro grid for independent and reliable power supply to meet the increasing local demands which cannot be guaranteed by conventional, central generation based electricity networks, especially during disastrous situations. This MRI project will develop a new state-of-the-art platform for incorporating the micro grid and smart grid technologies, which are urgently needed for deployment of new concepts, methods and tools for smart micro grids. The Howard University (HU), in collaboration with University of Denver (DU), will design, build, and construct real-time, highly flexible testbed and tools that will facilitate advancing the design and implementation of micro grid and smart grid. The testbed will benefit multi-users including students and faculty at HU and other partner universities and local electric power utility companies. In addition, the testbed will also be available as a national asset for standards organization like National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) and policy makers in the Washington, DC area to try out their ideas and learn about tools being developed in support of smart- and micro-grid. This will also serve as a research and educational tool to attract, recruit, and retain students in STEM disciplines. The research infrastructure will provide a real time platform that external broad users can utilize for hands-on experience. Minority and underrepresented students and researchers will be attracted to the testbed for advanced studies of important power and energy systems.

This MRI Development Project aims at the following objectives: (1) Design and develop a highly reconfigurable micro-grid testbed for testing micro grid designs; (2) Deploy distributed Phasor Measurement Units (PMU), Phasor Data Concentrator (PDC) and a smart grid testbed with Real-Time Digital Simulators (RTDS); (3) Develop tools to study the impact and usage of renewable energy resources in the smart grid and micro grid through real time modeling and hardware-in-the-loop simulation; (4) Develop platforms for various standards development, real time visualization, and application development for smart and micro grids. The flexible research and education testbed will facilitate advancing current work in the design and implementation of smart grid that will create opportunities for the study of large interconnected micro grids and smart-grid networks. This will be achieved by having multi-university collaboration with experts who are actively engaged in the design and implementation of micro and smart grid technology. This open-access testbed will be used for decision support, performance study, protocol evaluation, standards developments and testing of security requirements and automation functions with interoperability of new technological devices needed for development of future smart- and micro-grid technologies. This platform will also readily equip students and professionals with state-of-the-art knowledge. The benefit of this collaboration will open doors for many players including the research centers at Howard University, the utility companies, collaborating universities, military bases, and government agencies to use the University micro-grid as a testbed for validating new design, prototypes and research while building new transformational educational courses. The principal investigators and senior personnel of this project will pursue a holistic range of activities to promote the usage of the MRI testbed for research-integrated education and outreach, for training at all levels: from pre-college students through postdoctoral fellow and young faculty to engage creative and innovative ideas. This will promote growth among participants and attract more underrepresented minority to major in power and energy systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Major Research Instrumentation (MRI), grant no. 0008480, awarded to Howard University by National Science Foundation (NSF) is aimed at development of testbed platform for advanced multi-stage automation and control of smart grid and micro grid systems. The project allows us to develop modeling, optimization, and control of a micro grid system using state of the art simulation technologies. The project was conducted by Howard University in collaboration with University of Denver.

During the research, several innovative design methodologies were put in place and different advanced modeling techniques were developed that contributes to the improvements of the existing modeling platforms to perform multiple studies.

The specific contributions of the research and development work are in following major areas:

  • Development and testing of micro grid testbed using state of the art modeling and simulation tools capable of testing control and optimization functions.
  • Development and testing of frequency and Voltage/Var control functions on the testbed using stochastic optimal power flow concepts accounting for the uncertainty due to renewable energy resources and load.
  • Simulation and testing of optimal storage battery sizing and Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) application in micro grids and development of consensus-based algorithm for economic dispatch problem using advanced simulation and computational platforms.
  • Development and testing of cyber security and anomaly-based detection methods using real time simulation data to protect power system data against attacks and malicious manipulations.

Intellectual Impact:

The grant has led to innovative research and development works that includes:

  • Design of a micro grid network embedded with storage systems, static and dynamic loads, various measurement units and renewable energy resources connected to the micro grid network for performance study.
  • Analysis of control functions and use of emerging communication and measurement techniques that are evaluated and found successful for studies in the design and deployment of micro grid system with smart features. The output of this has helped to provide a general-purpose platform for research and education.
  • Modeling of micro grid system using advanced simulation tools such as Real Time Digital Simulator (RTDS) and MATLAB that are used to test the accuracy and efficiency of control functions under different contingencies for different selective objectives/goals for the network.
  • Development of new stochastic optimization method based on interior point method for solving load frequency control problem and Fuzzy/Neural logic Control for optimizing Voltage /Var control problem. These computational techniques have been properly tested on standardized micro grid networks developed in real time simulator for performance evaluation.
  • Development of advanced simulation-based algorithm using consensus-based algorithm for economic dispatch problem optimizing storage batteries and V2G application in micro grid. This is an innovative scheme for improving the performance of economic dispatch computations.
  • Training opportunity for over 4 post-doctoral researchers towards advancing their career in the areas of micro grid and smart grid modeling and control. In addition, it also helped cultivate young researchers from high school and universities worldwide to get hands on exposure in machines, power system, micro grid, and smart grid applications.
  • Collaboration of students from various universities in the US such as University of Denver, Howard University, George Mason University, and others leading to graduation of more than 6 PhD students and publication of above 20 technical papers. Students who graduated are now staffs at various universities in the US and abroad.

Broader Impact:

  • The testbed and simulation platform has created a research facility at Howard University where visiting professors and graduate students from US and abroad come to do research in power system modeling, optimization, control, and cyber security.
  • The output of the project has been evaluated for possible adaptation in the utility and other non-utility systems.
  • The project led to development of teaching infrastructure to serve existing and new student at Howard in undergraduate and graduate level.
  • Two books, titled “Adaptive Stochastic Optimization Techniques with Application” and “Energy Processing and Smart Grids”, were published by John Wiley & Sons as part of teaching materials at several schools.
  • Female and underrepresented communities were the major beneficiaries from the project by creating opportunity for them to pursue their graduate studies in M.Sc., PhD, and postdoctoral levels.

Given the impact of the work and the opportunity it created, the platform at Howard will be used for the development of new research directives and proposal to get new grants from NSF, Ministry of Defense and others and continue cultivating competitive scientists in the area. In addition, the testbed will be used to train pre-college engineering students, graduate students and new post doc researchers and expand the work by developing different objective function and control of micro grid and smart grid networks.
